metadata.title: Two-step pyrolysis of ZIF-8 functionalized with ammonium ferric citrate for efficient oxygen reduction reaction

MEA active area: 4.41 cm2; Nafion 212 membrane; cathode catalyst loading: 2.3 mg/cm2; anode catalyst: 40% Pt/C with a loading of 1.0 mg/cm2. No back pressure was applied. Table 1 Catalyst N content (wt%, XPS) Fe content (wt%, ICP) BET surface area (m2/g) Micropore surface area (m2/g) External surface area (m2/g) V total (cm3/g) a V µ (cm3/g) b C-ZIF-8 (2/0) 11.7 1.2 622.4 406.8 215.6 0.908 0.175 C-ZIF-8 (2/2) 5.0 4.7 1263.9 678.9 585.0 2.600 0.304 C-ZIF-8 (4/0) 10.2 1.5 689.0 546.8 142.2 0.904 0.224 C-ZIF-8 (4/2) 4.4 5.2 1323.7 787.1 536.6 2.638 0.341 a V total represents the total pore volume, determined at P/P 0 = 0.994; b V µ represents the volume of micropore as confirmed by t-plot method. ☆ Foundation item: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grants 21573222, 21622607, 91545202 and U1532117), the Strategic Priority Research Program of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (Grant No. XDB17020200), CAS Youth Innovation Promotion and K. C. Wong Education Foundation in Ningbo University. Two-step pyrolysis of ZIF-8 functionalized with ammonium ferric citrate for efficient oxygen reduction reaction Yifan Ye a b Fan Cai a b Chengcheng Yan a b Yanshuo Li c Guoxiong Wang a * Xinhe Bao a * a State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian Liaoning 116023 China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China c School of Material Science and Chemical Engineering, Ningbo University, Ningbo 315211, Zhejiang, China School of Material Science and Chemical Engineering Ningbo University Ningbo Zhejiang 315211 China * Corresponding authors. Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) are widely employed in catalyst synthesis as parental materials for electrochemical energy storage and conversion. Herein, we have demonstrated a facile synthesis of highly efficient catalyst for oxygen reduction reaction in both alkaline and acidic medium, which is derived from ZIF-8 functionalized with ammonium ferric citrate via two-step pyrolysis in Ar and NH3 atmosphere. The results reveal that the catalytic activity improvement after NH3 pyrolysis benefits from mesopore-dominated morphology and high utilization of Fe-containing active sites. The optimum catalyst shows excellent performance in zinc-air battery and polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell tests. Graphical abstract ZIF-8 derived carbon material via two-step pyrolysis in Ar and NH3 atmosphere, demonstrates excellent performance towards oxygen reduction reaction in both alkaline and acidic medium, which also shows superior activities in polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell and zinc-air battery tests. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks Two-step pyrolysis Oxygen reduction reaction Zinc-air battery Polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell 1 Introduction Electrochemical energy storage and conversion techniques have attracted much attention in recent years with the increasing consumption of fossil resources and environmental threat [1,2]. Polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) and zinc-air battery are typical electrochemical power sources with high power density and energy efficiency, in which oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is an important electrocatalytic process [3–6]. Platinum is widely recognized as the state-of-the-art ORR catalyst in both acidic and alkaline medium [7–9]. However, the widespread application of platinum-based catalysts is severely hampered by their high cost and scarcity in the nature [10,11]. Therefore, designing applicable and inexpensive ORR catalysts becomes increasingly important against the background of energy crisis and rarity of noble metals [12,13]. As alternatives, non-precious metal with Fe–N–C structure have hitherto been substantiated to display outstanding ORR performance in both alkaline and acidic medium [14,15]. Considering the sluggish kinetics of ORR, the excellent catalytic performance is usually a combination of abundant active sites and fast diffusion of oxygen and intermediate species [16,17]. The general problem is that most Fe–N–C sites buried in the bulk of carbon matrix cannot be comprehensively utilized in catalyzing ORR [18]. In the scenarios, highly doped and exposed metal-nitrogen sites within carbon frameworks have been successfully prepared and widely used in catalyst design by controlled synthesis [19,20]. However, more strategies need to be employed in order to further enhance their catalytic performance. Multistep pyrolysis developed by Sun and co-workers and Strasser and co-workers is the most promising methodology to effectively improve the catalytic performance of Fe-based carbon materials [21,22]. Repeated pyrolysis can effectively remove unstable species and meanwhile create a more porous morphology, resulting in a density increment of active sites and enhanced mass transfer simultaneously [23]. Inspired by their work, we herein explore a two-step pyrolysis in Ar and NH3 atmosphere, to improve the utilization of active sites and facilitate mass transfer. The optimum catalyst exhibits excellent electrochemical activity after NH3 pyrolysis in both alkaline and acidic medium, even exceeding commercial 40 wt% Pt/C in alkaline medium. The maximum power density of the optimum catalyst in PEMFC and zinc–air battery could reach 391 mW/cm2 and 224 mW/cm2, respectively. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Synthesis of ZIF-8 The preparation of ZIF-8 was conducted by the following method developed by Yang and co-workers with minor modifications [24]. 11.90 g of Zn(NO3)2•6H2O (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) and 26.27 g of 2-methylimidazole (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) were homogeneously mixed in 400 mL methanol solution at room temperature. The solution was kept statically for another 48 h after vigorous stirring for 1 h. The precipitate was refined by centrifugation with methanol for three times, followed by drying under vacuum at room temperature overnight. 2.1.2 Synthesis of AFC©ZIF-8 Typically, 1.0 g of as-synthesized ZIF-8 was added to 20 mL of deionized water containing 0.06 g ammonium ferric citrate (AFC, C6H11FeNO7, 16.9 wt% Fe, J&K Chemical Ltd). The mixture was vigorously stirred for 24 h at room temperature, and then washed with deionized water for three times, followed by drying in oven at 60 °C overnight. The final powder was denoted as AFC©ZIF-8. 2.1.3 Synthesis of C-ZIF-8 (2/0) and C-ZIF-8 (4/0) 0.6 g of as-synthesized AFC©ZIF-8 was heated to 900 °C at a rate of 3 °C/min and kept at 900 °C for 2 h or 4 h in Ar atmosphere at a flow rate of 100 mL/min, followed by cooling down to room temperature. The black products were washed in 150 mL 0.5 M HClO4 solution at 80 °C for 10 h to remove the unstable species, followed by washing in deionized water and drying in oven at 60 °C overnight. The final products were denoted as C-ZIF-8 (2/0) and C-ZIF-8 (4/0), respectively. 2.1.4 Synthesis of C-ZIF-8 (2/2) and C-ZIF-8 (4/2) 0.1 g of C-ZIF-8 (2/0) was heated to 900 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min in Ar atmosphere and kept at 900 °C for 2 h in NH3 atmosphere at a flow rate of 50 mL/min and then cooled down naturally in Ar atmosphere. The final product was used without any post-treatment and denoted as C-ZIF-8 (2/2). 0.1 g of C-ZIF-8 (4/0) was treated under the same condition as described above, and the final product was denoted as C-ZIF-8 (4/2). 2.2 Physicochemical characterization The morphologies of the samples were investigated via a JEM-2100 high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) operated at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed using a PANalytical X'pert PPR diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.5418 Å) at 40 kV and 40 mA with a scan rate of 5°/min. Raman spectroscopy was conducted on a Jobin Yvon LabRAM HR 800 instrument with a 532 nm excitation laser at a power of around 0.8 mW. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were acquired using a Quantachrome Autosorb iQ2 system at −196 °C. The specific surface areas of all the samples were calculated by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on a Thermo Scientific Spectrometer with an Escalab 250 Xi X-ray as the excitation source. The Fe loadings of all the samples were measured by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). 2.3 Electrochemical measurements 5 mg catalyst was mixed with 1.7 mL ethanol, 0.3 mL deionized water, and 50 µL 5% Nafion (DuPont) solution under ultrasonication to generate a homogeneous ink. The well-dispersed ink was dripped onto the glassy carbon (GC) disk electrode (Ø 5.0 mm, 0.196 cm2) using micropipettes for electrochemical measurements with an Autolab potentiostat/galvanostat (PGSTAT 302 N). 25 µL of the as-prepared ink was used in alkaline medium with a catalyst loading of 311 µg/cm2, while 50 µL of the ink was used in acidic electrolyte with a catalyst loading of 622 µg/cm2. As a comparison, the loading of 40 wt% Pt/C (Tanaka Kikinzoku Kogyo K. K.) is 25 µgPt/cm2 using the same ink preparation method for electrochemical measurements in both alkaline and acidic medium. The electrolyte solution, 0.1 M KOH or 0.1 M HClO4 solution, was bubbled with O2 vigorously to guarantee an O2-saturated environment under electrochemical measurements. The catalyst on the GC disk electrode was subjected to potential range from −0.8 V to 0.2 V (versus Hg/HgO) or from −0.2 V to 0.8 V (versus Ag/AgCl) at a scan rate of 10 mV/s with a rotation rate of 2500 rpm. The graphite rod electrode was adopted as the counter electrode. The net ORR current of the catalyst was calculated by deduction of the background capacitive current in an Ar-saturated electrolyte solution. The potential difference between the Hg/HgO reference electrode and RHE is 0.925 V and the potential difference between the Ag/AgCl reference electrode and RHE is 0.267 V. The rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) was employed to record the current fluctuations in the disk and ring in O2-saturated 0.1 M HClO4 solution. 50 µL of the as-prepared ink was dropped onto the GC disk (Ø 5.7 mm) of the RRDE with a polycrystalline Pt biased at 1.20 V (versus RHE) and a rotation rate of 2500 rpm. The following equations were adopted for the calculation of electron transfer number and H2O2 selectivity: (1) n = 4 * I d I d + I r / N 0 (2) H 2 O 2 ( % ) = 200 * I r N 0 * I d + I r where, I d and I r are the measured disk and ring currents, respectively; n represents the electron transfer number in the ORR test; N 0 is the collection efficiency (0.38). Different solutions were adopted to investigate the effects of inorganic ions upon the catalyst activity. Polarization curves were obtained in both Ar-saturated and O2-saturated electrolyte solution with the addition of targeted substance (e.g., KF, KCl, KBr and KSCN). 2.4 Zinc–air battery tests For the cathode preparation of zinc–air battery, a carbon black ink containing Vulcan XC-72R carbon black and polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) according to a mass ratio of 3:2 was painted onto the Toray TGP-H-060 (Toray Industries Inc.) to form a diffusion layer. The carbon black loading was about 1 mg/cm2. The catalyst was first ultrasonically dispersed in a mixture of water, ethanol and Nafion solution (5 wt%, DuPont), and then brushed onto the diffusion layer at 70 °C. The catalyst loading in the cathode was 1.0 mg/cm2. A home-made zinc–air battery device was employed for performance evaluation. 6 M KOH solution and zinc plate (anode) were used in the primary zinc–air battery test. Discharge polarization curve was recorded by an Autolab potentiostat/galvanostat (PGSTAT 302 N). 2.5 PEMFC test The membrane electrode assembly (MEA) was fabricated for PEMFC test. The catalyst layers in the anode and cathode were brushed on the gas diffusion layer based on Toray TGP-H-060, respectively. The commercial 40 wt% Pt/C (TKK, Japan) with a catalyst loading of 1.0 mg/cm2 was adopted as the anode catalyst layer and the C-ZIF-8 (4/2) with a catalyst loading of 2.3 mg/cm2 as the cathode catalyst layer. The Nafion content in the cathode catalyst layer was about 50 wt% to enhance protonic conductivity. Then the anode and cathode (2.1 cm × 2.1 cm) were placed onto the two sides of a Nafion NRE-212 membrane (DuPont) and hot-pressed at 135 °C under 1 MPa for 3 min to form the MEA. The single cell performance was tested on a fuel cell testing system (FC IMPEDANCE METER KFM2030, KIKUSUI Corp.) equipped with mass flow-rate controllers and humidifiers for the reactant gases. During the single cell test, the cell temperature was held at 80 °C and the H2/O2 humidifier temperatures were set as 85 °C. Pure H2 and O2 were fed into the anode and cathode with a flow rate of 60 mL/min and 300 mL/min at ambient pressure, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure, morphology and composition Analysis Typically, the as-synthesized ZIF-8 was immersed in ammonium ferric citrate solution to prepare the AFC©ZIF-8 via surface functionalization under ambient condition [25–27]. The white ZIF-8 powder gradually turned yellowish and the iron weight percent in AFC©ZIF-8 sample determined by ICP–OES was 0.7 wt%. TEM and HRTEM images in Fig. 1 (a)–(d) show the morphology of ZIF-8 and AFC©ZIF-8, indicating that the structure of ZIF-8 architecture is well preserved after surface functionalization with AFC, which is also confirmed by XRD patterns in Fig. 1(e). After pyrolysis in Ar atmosphere, there are only two broad peaks corresponding to carbon for both C-ZIF-8 (2/0) and C-ZIF-8 (4/0), as shown in Fig. 1(f). The decomposition of ZIF-8 skeleton and elimination of Zn above 550 °C are beneficial for porous carbon formation [28]. AFC begins to transform into graphitic carbon, accompanied with the reduction of iron species in the temperature range from 540 °C to 620 °C [29]. Therefore, the coincident temperature window of ZIF-8 and ammonium ferric citrate during pyrolysis effectively avoids the agglomeration of iron species, thus favoring high dispersion of Fe–N active sites embedded within carbon matrix in C-ZIF-8 (2/0) and C-ZIF-8 (4/0) as indicated by TEM and HRTEM images (Fig. 2 a–d), which was further confirmed by our previous work [30]. After NH3 pyrolysis, some iron nanoparticles form in C-ZIF-8 (2/2) and C-ZIF-8 (4/2) due to the reducibility of NH3 and perhaps the etching of unstable carbon and nitrogen species by NH3 (Figs. 1f and 2e–h). Raman spectra of all the catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 (a). The intensity ratio of G band to D band (I G/I D) as calculated from the peak intensity is between 0.89 and 0.99, indicative of similar graphitization degree [31]. The specific surface areas of different samples were measured via N2 adsorption–desorption at −196 °C (Fig. 3b). The BET surface area and total pore volume of C-ZIF-8 (4/2) are 1323.7 m2/g and 2.638 cm3/g, while those of C-ZIF-8 (4/0) are 689.0 m2/g and 0.904 cm3/g, respectively. After NH3 pyrolysis, some pores larger than 15 nm form in C-ZIF-8 (4/2) compared with those in C-ZIF-8 (4/0), suggesting that the introduction of NH3 during pyrolysis favors mesopore-dominated morphology (Table 1 and Fig. S1). XPS characterization indicates that the NH3 treatment not only removes unstable carbon species, but also eliminates some N species (Table 1 and Fig. S2). 3.2 Electrochemical measurements The electrocatalytic activities of the as-prepared catalysts were first evaluated in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution (Fig. 4 a). The ORR performance of C-ZIF-8 (4/0) is comparable to that of commercial 40 wt% Pt/C, while the onset potential and half-wave potential of the most active C-ZIF-8 (2/2) catalyst are 50 mV and 45 mV more positive than those of 40 wt% Pt/C, respectively. We further evaluate their electrochemical activities in O2-saturated 0.1 M HClO4 solution. As illustrated by the polarization curves in Fig. 4(b), the half-wave potential of C-ZIF-8 (4/2) catalyst is only 21 mV lower than that of 40 wt% Pt/C. We have demonstrated the presence of isolated Fe–N sites confined within carbon matrix in the catalysts before. Theoretically, some mechanisms for Fe–N sites activating the oxygen were reported according to the DFT calculation [32,33]. The chemisorption of an O2 molecule on the Fe–N structure is considered to initialize the ORR over the catalyst [34]. After the O2 adsorption, the four-electron ORR on the Fe–N structure could continue through three possible reaction pathways: (i) O2 dissociation, (ii) OOH dissociation, and (iii) HOOH dissociation [35,36]. The H2O2 yield of the catalysts in acidic medium suggests that the ORR of four catalysts all follows a near-4 electron pathway in the potential range from 0.20 V to 0.80 V (versus RHE), resulting in a small amount of H2O2 below 6% (Fig. 4c) [37]. After 10,000 potential cycles, C-ZIF-8 (4/2) only shows slightly deteriorated ORR performance with 12 mV negative shift in half-wave potential (Fig. 4d). Halide (F−, Cl−, Br−) and pseudohalide (SCN−) ions can coordinate with metal-ions, thus prohibiting the ORR activity and providing evidence to ascertain the active sites in the catalyst [23]. Fig. 5 (a)–(d) compares the polarization curves of C-ZIF-8 (4/2) in O2-saturated 0.1 M HClO4 solution before and after the addition of 10 mM F−, Cl−, Br− and SCN− ions. The negative shift of the half-wave potential follows the sequence of SCN−> F− > Br− > Cl−, being 72, 32, 13, and 9 mV, respectively. These results clearly substantiate that the active sites of C-ZIF-8 (4/2) should contain Fe element because these anions are highly active in coordinating with Fe species. Sun and co-workers proposed that the valence state is mainly FeIII because SCN− only strongly coordinates with FeIII rather than FeII, thus seriously retarding the ORR process and lowering the half-wave potential [23]. Mukerjee and co-workers proposed that the FeIII/ FeII transformation during the test was crucial for the ORR via in-situ and ex-situ characterizations [38]. Therefore, the factors that influence the FeIII/ FeII pair would change the reaction process and the half-wave potential. It is well known that the mesopores favor mass transfer during the electrocatalytic reaction [39,40]. The high electrochemical activity of C-ZIF-8 (4/2) may be attributed to the increase of mesoporosity after NH3 pyrolysis [41]. Iron nanoparticles form after NH3 heat treatment, which will decrease the amount of active sites. However, the decrease in active sites is offset by the removal of unstable carbon and nitrogen species during the pyrolysis in NH3 atmosphere. When the deterioration of active sites is slower than the decrease of total mass of the catalyst (ca. 3/4 total mass loss), an increase in ORR activity is achieved in C-ZIF-8 (4/2). Pyrolysis in NH3 atmosphere is to attune the density of active sites as well as bring ever-increasing mesopores for high utilization of active sites [42]. All these results indicate that the high ORR activity of C-ZIF-8 (4/2) should originate from the increase of active site density and high mesoporosity. 3.3 Zinc-air battery and PEMFC tests C-ZIF-8 (4/2) catalyst was brushed onto the carbon paper to function as the air electrode for primary zinc–air batteries. The discharge i–V curve and power density plot in Fig. 6 (a) suggest that the maximum power density reaches 224 mW/cm2 at cell voltage of 0.70 V (versus Zn) and current density of 0.319 A/cm2 in 6 M KOH solution. We also carried out PEMFC test by employing the C-ZIF-8 (4/2) catalyst as the cathode catalyst. Fig. 6(b) shows the PEMFC polarization curve and power density plot. The open circuit voltage is 0.927 V and the maximum power density reaches 391 mW/cm2 at cell voltage of 0.35 V and current density of 1.12 A/cm2 at ambient pressure. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have explored a two-step pyrolysis of ZIF-8 functionalized with ammonium ferric citrate in Ar and NH3 atmosphere to improve the ORR performance both in alkaline and acidic medium. The first-step pyrolysis in Ar atmosphere converted the ZIF-8 functionalized with ammonium ferric citrate into carbon nanomaterials doped with well-dispersed Fe–N active sites, and the subsequent pyrolysis in NH3 atmosphere improves the mesoporous area as well as the formation of undesirable iron nanoparticles. By varying the pyrolysis time, the optimal C-ZIF-8 (4/2) catalyst exhibits high ORR activities in alkaline and acidic medium, as well as high performance in zinc–air battery and PEMFC tests. The two-step pyrolysis provides an attractive route to synthesize highly efficient ORR catalysts derived from ZIF-8. coredata.dc:description: Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) are widely employed in catalyst synthesis as parental materials for electrochemical energy storage and conversion. Herein, we have demonstrated a facile synthesis of highly efficient catalyst for oxygen reduction reaction in both alkaline and acidic medium, which is derived from ZIF-8 functionalized with ammonium ferric citrate via two-step pyrolysis in Ar and NH3 atmosphere. The results reveal that the catalytic activity improvement after NH3 pyrolysis benefits from mesopore-dominated morphology and high utilization of Fe-containing active sites. The optimum catalyst shows excellent performance in zinc-air battery and polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell tests.

coredata.dc:title: Two-step pyrolysis of ZIF-8 functionalized with ammonium ferric citrate for efficient oxygen reduction reaction
